content:
Let SSS be a commutative ring. Let RRR be an algebra over SSS ie. a commutative ring with a morphism S→RS \rightarrow RS→R. Can SSS be an algebra over RRR in two different ways, ie. can we have two morphisms of rings i:R→Si:R \rightarrow Si:R→S and j:R→Sj:R \rightarrow Sj:R→S such that i≠ji \neq ji=j?

I'm pretty sure the answer is yes and it should be easy but I don't have an example. It would be surprising that there can't be more than one morphism between two rings :big_smile:. Do you have an easy example or a proof that it is false? Maybe it depends of the ring R,SR,SR,S, if they are field or not, of the characteristics...

All I know is that for a Z\mathbb{Z}Z-algebra SSS, it is an algebra in a unique way, because Z\mathbb{Z}Z is the initial object in the category of commutative rings...

For example the ring of integer polynomials Z[X]\Bbb{Z}[X]Z[X] can be mapped to Z\Bbb{Z}Z by evaluating the polynomials by setting XXX to a particular integer. So there is one morphism Z[X]→Z\Bbb{Z}[X]\to\Bbb{Z}Z[X]→Z for each integer.
Oh nice, thanks!
Another simple example would be that complex conjugation is a morphism C→C\Bbb{C}\to\Bbb{C}C→C, distinct from the identity.
But it would feel weird to phrase that as 'C\Bbb{C}C is a C\Bbb{C}C-algebra in two different ways'.

Maybe saying that C\mathbb{C}C is a C\mathbb{C}C-algebra in a unique way makes sense because ring morphisms from a field are always injective so that the image of a field in an algebra over a field is unique up to isomorphism but for rings that's not necessarily the case...

So I think that your previous example really shows that Z\mathbb{Z}Z is a Z[X]\mathbb{Z}[X]Z[X]-algebra in two different ways because if you change the value you set XXX two, you change the image of the morphism.
I think you wrote 'bijective' when you meant 'injective'. Morphisms out of fields are not necessarily bijective, for example R→C\Bbb{R}\to\Bbb{C}R→C.
Oh yes thanks
Also, I think the image of Z[X]→Z\Bbb{Z}[X]\to\Bbb{Z}Z[X]→Z is always Z\Bbb{Z}Z, because polynomials include constants.
But yes, there's no automorphism fff of Z\Bbb{Z}Z such that f∘eval2=eval3f\circ \mathrm{eval}_2 = \mathrm{eval}_3f∘eval2​=eval3​.
So, do you have an example of two ring morphisms f,g:R→Sf,g:R \rightarrow Sf,g:R→S such that im(f)≇im(g)im(f) \not\cong im(g)im(f)≅im(g)?

Again, Z[X]\Bbb{Z}[X]Z[X] is useful because you can set XXX to be whatever you want. So for example in the ring Z[Y,Z]/Y2\Bbb{Z}[Y,Z]/Y^2Z[Y,Z]/Y2 there's no automorphism taking YYY to ZZZ, because YYY squares to 0 and ZZZ doesn't. So then if we consider the maps Z[X]→Z[Y,Z]/Y2\Bbb{Z}[X]\to\Bbb{Z}[Y,Z]/Y^2Z[X]→Z[Y,Z]/Y2, one of which sends XXX to YYY and the other of which sends XXX to ZZZ, their images will look completely different.

For an example with fields, consider Q[X]/(X3−1)\mathbb{Q}[X]/(X^3 - 1)Q[X]/(X3−1). This has three homomorphisms to C\mathbb{C}C, mapping XXX to the respective roots of unity. One of them has image contained in the reals, the other two do not.
Okay, so it even exists with fields.

Recently the question whether R\mathbb{R}R-algebra structure is unique in this sense came up on MathOverflow and nobody seemed to know the answer (although that was in a comment, so not many people may have seen the question). Perhaps someone here can make progress on this? Note that R\mathbb{R}R has no field automorphisms.

I think that maybe for augmented R\mathbb{R}R-algebras it could be the case that they are R\mathbb{R}R-algebras in a unique way. An augmented R\mathbb{R}R-algebra is a R\mathbb{R}R-algebra i:R→Ai:\mathbb{R} \rightarrow Ai:R→A together with an augmentation g:A→Rg:A \rightarrow \mathbb{R}g:A→R ie. a ring homomorphism such that i;g=Idi;g=Idi;g=Id.

It would be the case that two R\mathbb{R}R-algebras A,BA,BA,B whose underlying rings are isomorphic are also isomorphic as R\mathbb{R}R-algebras if either AAA or BBB is augmented, if the unique ring epimorphism R→R\mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}R→R was the identity (edit: in fact, I don't know).
And I also suspect that every non-zero R\mathbb{R}R-algebra is augmented.

Beware of your intuition here. There is at most one ring homomorphism from Q\mathbb{Q}Q, and since this is dense in R\RR, a continuous ring homomorphism from R\RR is unique if it exists. Any counterexample would therefore be discontinuous, and one may be constructible using the axiom of choice, for example by constructing a sufficiently "nice" Q\mathbb{Q}Q-basis of R\RR and mapping the basis elements to different places.

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

It would be the case that two R\mathbb{R}R-algebras A,BA,BA,B whose underlying rings are isomorphic are also isomorphic as R\mathbb{R}R-algebras if either AAA or BBB is augmented, if the unique ring epimorphism R→R\mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}R→R was the identity.

I don't understand the argument here, could you explain?

You are right, it doesn't work, I wanted to write:

"Firstly, given two R\mathbb{R}R-algebras i:R→Ai:\mathbb{R} \rightarrow Ai:R→A, j:R→Bj:\mathbb{R} \rightarrow Bj:R→B, a ring homomorphism f:A→Bf:A \rightarrow Bf:A→B is a R\mathbb{R}R-algebra homomorphism iff i;f=ji;f=ji;f=j.
If AAA is augmented, you have a ring homomorphism g:A→Rg:A \rightarrow \mathbb{R}g:A→R such that i;g=Idi;g=Idi;g=Id.
Then ggg is a ring epimorphism.
If f:A→Bf:A \rightarrow Bf:A→B is a ring isomorphism, then j;f−1;g:R→Rj;f^{-1};g:\mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}j;f−1;g:R→R is a ring epimorphism.
So, if the unique ring epimporphism R→R\mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}R→R is the identity, then j;f−1;g=Idj;f^{-1};g = Idj;f−1;g=Id."
(If you had g;i=Idg;i=Idg;i=Id, it would give j;f−1=ij;f^{-1}=ij;f−1=i and then f−1f^{-1}f−1 would be a R\mathbb{R}R-algebra homomorphism, but in this case A≅B≅RA \cong B \cong \mathbb{R}A≅B≅R...)

Maybe it could be true for connected graded R\mathbb{R}R-algebras ie. the ones of the form ⨁n≥0An\underset{n \ge 0}{\bigoplus}A_{n}n≥0⨁​An​ where A0≅RA_{0} \cong \mathbb{R}A0​≅R and AiAj⊆Ai+jA_{i}A_{j}\subseteq A_{i+j}Ai​Aj​⊆Ai+j​ (still if the unique epimorphism R→R\mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}R→R is the identity.)
I'm gonna try to see if it works in these conditions...

Anyway, I have absolutely no intuition for the discontinuous ring homorphisms. So, I hope someone is gonna solve your problem. As to me, I learned a lot about ring and algebra homomorphisms in this thread.
Good thinking in any case, thanks for sharing!
Here's something vaguely, not precisely, related to the question of whether there can be more than one ring homomorphism f:R→Rf: \mathbb{R} \to Rf:R→R for some ring RRR.

There's a concept of [[real closed field]]. Besides the real numbers R\mathbb{R}R we can find another real closed field R′\mathbb{R}'R′, not isomorphic to R\mathbb{R}R, with the same cardinality. We can build the complex numbers C\mathbb{C}C using pairs of real numbers. We can use the exact same formula to build a field C′\mathbb{C}'C′ using pairs of guys in R′\mathbb{R}'R′. But it’s easy to check that this funny field C′\mathbb{C}'C′ is algebraically closed and of characteristic zero. Since it has the same cardinality as C\mathbb{C}C, it must be isomorphic to C\mathbb{C}C.
So, C\mathbb{C}C contains real closed fields other than R\mathbb{R}R.
And what is this R′\mathbb{R}'R′? Does it have a name?

I believe there are many real closed fields with same cardinality as the reals. You can use any one as R′\mathbb{R}'R′. For example, you can use the field of Puiseaux series with real coefficients. You can also use the field of hyperreal numbers.
